Graphical abstract Five strategies for preparing TM-SACs based on MOFs and their derived structures are summarized, concerning with advanced characterization techniques, structural evaluation and prospects of TM-SAC. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been widely used in oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) of fuel cells and metal-air batteries, attributed to their unique structures and compositions. Recently, the preparation of transition-metallic single-atom electrocatalysts (TM-SACs) using MOFs as precursors or templates has made great progress. Herein, the development history of SACs prepared based on MOFs and their characterization are overviewed firstly, and then several strategies are summarized for preparing TM-SACs using MOFs and further modification. Finally, the challenges and opportunities confronted by TM-SACs are fully discussed. Consequently, our work can guide the realization of TM-SACs abundant with high activity, high loading and high stability. Keywords Transition-metallic single-atom electrocatalysts (TM-SACs) Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) Electron microscopy Spectroscopy 1 Introduction Electrochemical energy storage and conversion system mainly include metal-ion batteries [1–4], dual-ion batteries [5,6], supercapacitors [7–12], metal-air batteries, and fuel cells [13–15], etc. The latter two are clean, safe and reliable energy devices with the advantages of environment friendliness, high energy density, rich source of raw materials and long working time [16,17]. Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is a crucial process for fuel cells and suffers from sluggish reaction kinetics [18–23]. Herein, electrocatalysts are essentially needed to enhance the reaction process [24]. Crucially, the catalytic activity of electrocatalysts determines the overall efficiency and output power in fuel cells. Usually, ORR catalysts are mainly divided into noble-metal catalysts [25–28], metal-free catalysts [29–33] and non-noble metal catalysts [34–38]. Noble-metal catalysts, such as commercial platinum-based catalysts, have excellent ORR activity. However, they are largely limited as of their high cost, poor stability and easy poisoning, which largely hinder their large-scale application [39–43]. Metal-free catalysts are mainly carbon materials, such as heteroatom-doped carbon and some typical carbon structures (graphene, carbon nanotubes, graphite array, and amorphous carbon) [31,44,45]. Based on the difference of electric neutrality and atomic radius between doped and carbon atoms, heteroatom-doped modification enables regulating the charge distribution and geometric structure of carbon materials, thus breaking the symmetry of charge distribution of carbon supports. Transition-metal nitrogen carbon catalysts (TM-N-C), as typical non-noble metal catalysts, have the advantages of low cost, high structural stability and high activity. In 2011, Zhang’s group gave the proof-of-concept for single-atom electrocatalysts (thereafter as SACs), as shining stars already active in the field of catalysis [46]. SACs have the advantages of ideal atomic utilization efficiency, high catalytic activity, high catalytic selectivity and high stability. Their high catalytic activity is closely correlated to the high atomic utilization efficiency and special electronic structure of the metal-centered atoms with unsaturated coordination [47–51]. According to metallic types, single metal atoms loaded on the supports can be divided into main-group metals and transition-group metals. Since main-group (s-block and p-block) metals have delocalized s/p-band, they are generally considered to have poor catalytic activity. In order to improve the catalytic activity of main-group metals, their electronic structures are usually modified by doping other elements to promote the transfer of charges and the adsorption of intermediate products, thereby reducing the reaction barrier [52,53]. Jiao and co-workers used zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) as templates to synthesize SACs with the Sb-N4 structure, and the loading of the Sb is as high as 0.79 wt% [54]. The high ORR activity is mainly attributed to the interaction between the p orbital of Sb atom and the O2-p orbital to form a hybrid state. As a result, it promotes the charge transfer process and the adsorption of intermediate products. Other main-group metals, such as Bi and Sn, have been more reported in CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR). Transition-group metals, are referred to series of metal elements in the d zone for the Periodic Table. Due to the unfilled valence layer d orbital of transition metal, the special electronic structure renders an appropriate adsorption strength with the ORR reaction intermediate product, thereby producing an excellent ORR activity [55–57]. Recently, transition-metallic single-atom electrocatalysts (TM-SACs) are booming because of their excellent catalytic activity (Fe > Co > Mn > Cu > Ni), low cost and excellent stability [58,59]. In addition, they are superior to platinum-based catalysts in terms of toxicity resistance. Thus, TM-SACs are particularly suitable for the fuel cells working in a complex working environment, i.e., acting as an excellent alternative to noble-metal catalysts. However, the particularly high specific surface energy renders those individual atoms to easily agglomerate in the preparation process, which leads to some difficulties in the preparation method of SACs [60]. Concurrently, it remains challenging to achieve large-scale and universal preparation of SACs. Therefore, it remains greatly challenging to realize the preparation of SACs with high metallic loading and high activity. As an excellent precursor for the synthesis of TM-SACs, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) provide many useful options. MOFs are periodic and porous crystalline materials consisting of metal ions/clusters and organic ligands via self-assembly, and the diversity of components renders MOFs with a rich variety. They are involved with applications in catalysis, electrochemical energy storage and gas separation [61–63]. MOFs afford the advantages of ultra-high specific surface area, adjustable pore structure, high porosity, diverse selection of metal ions and ligands, structural topology and structural diversity. MOFs are interesting precursors and templates for the preparation of TM-SACs through pyrolysis [64–66]. The advantages of using MOFs as precursors to prepare TM-SACs are mainly reflected in the following points (Fig. 1 ) [67–71]:. 1) Metal ions can be assembled with organic ligands into a 3D crystal framework abundant with high porosity, high specific surface area as well as structural diversity. The pore structures inside the MOFs facilitate the mass transfer in the catalytic process and accommodates more active sites; 2) Abundant organic ligands in elemental composition can provide the conductive support and elemental doping after heating treatment; 3) A variety of modification treatments can be carried out on the basis of MOFs to give full play to their advantages. However, there are also some disadvantages to be overcome [72,73]: 1) MOFs are somehow not stable enough with the trendiness of structural collapse in pyrolysis; 2) Due to amounts of organic solvents used in synthesis, it is not friendly to the environment; 3) The single metal atoms in the structure will aggregate during the pyrolysis, unfavorable for the formation of SACs; 4) The preparation method is complicated and the subsequent picking treatment may be required. MOFs show great potential in the preparation of TM-SACs due to their adjustable structure and diversity of modification methods. The purpose of this review is to provide some comments and insights on the development of MOFs-derived TM-SACs in ORR and promote the development of TM-SACs in the field of energy conversion. First of all, our review summarizes the reaction mechanism and optimization principles of ORR. Secondly, the development history of the preparation of TM-SACs based on MOFs as well as their main characterization methods, and the correlation between structural feature and performance of catalysts are explored; Then based on amounts of previous work, the strategies for preparing TM-SACs using MOFs as precursors or templates are summarized into the following categories (Fig. 2): 1) Surface confinement strategy; 2) Cavity confinement strategy; 3) Outer protection strategy; 4) Phase diffusion strategy; 5) Dual-template strategy. Finally, we aim to illustrate amounts of recent progresses and provide some fundamental principles and horizons for the development of MOFs-derived TM-SACs. 2 Reaction mechanism and optimization principle of ORR ORR is known as a multi-electron reduction reaction, consisting of many elementary steps and accompanied by amounts of intermediate products. The adsorption strength of ORR-induced intermediate species and metal active sites determines the level of catalytic activity. ORR is usually divided into either four-electron or two-electron pathways. Theoretically, the four-electron pathway enables achieving a high energy conversion efficiency, as well as avoiding the generation of undesirable intermediate products [76–81]. The reaction pathways of ORR in both acidic and alkaline conditions are as following: 1) Acidic condition four-electron pathway: O2 + 4H+ + 4e− → 2H2O two-electron pathway: O2,ads + 2H+ + 2e− → H2O2 H2O2 + 2H++2e-→2H2O (H2O2 further oxidation) 2H2O2 → 2H2O + O2 (H2O2 further decomposition) 2) Alkaline condition four-electron pathway: O2 + 2H2O + 4e− → 4OH− two-electron pathway: O2,ads + H2O + 2e− → HO2 –+OH– HO2 – + H2O + 2e− → 3OH– (HO2 – further oxidation) 2HO2 – → 2OH– + O2 (HO2 – further decomposition) A general redox process is shown in Fig. 3 (a and b). Under the acidic condition, the oxygen molecule is firstly dissolved to form dissolved oxygen after entering the solution, and then diffuses to the catalyst surface for adsorption and chemical decomposition. H2O can be generated directly via the four-electron pathway. It can also go through a 2+2 electron pathway to form the intermediate product, H2O2, which is then further oxidized to H2O. H2O2 can also be chemically decomposed to adsorb oxygen and H2O, or can be also desorbed from the metal surface into the solution [83–85]. Under the alkaline condition, oxygen molecule enters the solution as the dissolved oxygen and then diffuses into the electrode surface. Oxygen molecule can be directly reduced to OH– through a four-electron pathway, or it may be first reduced to HO2 – through a 2+2 electron pathway, and HO2 – can be reduced to OH– through the two-electron pathway. HO2 – can also be catalyzed into O2 or OH– [80]. Anyhow, the reaction pathway of ORR is complex; the four-electron and two-electron pathways are usually proceeding simultaneously. The metal types are closely correlated with the detailed catalytic reaction pathway. For transition metals, the four-electron pathway often occurs on the metal surface with an offer of high activity (e.g., Pt and Pb), whereas the two-electron pathway affords low activity (e.g., Au and Hg) [82,86–89]. Therefore, the specific reaction mechanism remains to be explored for various metals. Due to the obvious difference in the ORR reaction mechanism under either acidic or alkali conditions, there are also some differences in the optimization principles. Studies showed that the poor ORR performance in the acidic condition is mainly due to the protonation of pyridine-N into the pyridine-N-H structure during the reaction process [90]. Since the ORR reaction is a proton-coupled electron transfer reaction, its reactivity depends on the supply rate of protons and electrons. Whereas in the acidic condition, protons instantly combine with pyridine-N through a strong electrostatic interaction, which hinders the coupling process of protons and electrons, resulting in poor performance. Based on the aforementioned discussion, the ORR performance in the acid condition can be improved in the following ways [91,92]: 1) Preventing the rapid combination of proton and pyridine-N in acidic environment. 2) Increasing the intrinsic activity and number of metal active sites. However, in alkaline, different from acidic conditions, most studies have proved that pyridine-N plays a positive role in the catalytic process. The increase of pyridine-N content has a positive effect on the improvement of ORR performance. Therefore, increasing the content of pyridine-N is an important mean to improve the ORR performance in the alkali condition [80,93]. Also, increasing the content of metal active sites and rationally designing the hierarchical porous structure of the support is conducive to exposing more active sites and improving the utilization of active sites, thereby improving catalytic activity. In addition, due to the different adsorption modes of oxygen molecules at the catalytic active sites, there exist some differences in the catalytic reaction mechanism and pathways [82]. The reaction modes are mainly classified as the following types (Fig. 3c): 1) Griffiths model: Oxygen molecule interacts laterally with a metal site. During the whole process, the π orbital of O2 interacts with the hollow dz2 orbital of the metal atom, weakening O-O bonding and dissociation adsorption of O2. This route is favorable for the four-electron reaction pathway; 2) Pauling model: One end of O2 interacts with a metal site. During the whole process, the O2 molecule interacts with the hollow dz2 of the metal atom via an empty π* orbital. Since only one side of O2 participates in the reaction, it is conducive to the two-electron reaction pathway; 3) Yeager model: Both the two sides of O2 interact concurrently with different metal sites. This action mode is similar to a bridge, also known as “bridge adsorption”. In this way, it allows for O2 to fully participate in the reaction. It is favorable for the four-electron reaction pathway. Both 1) and 2) belong to the single-site adsorption mode, whereas 3) belongs to the dual-site adsorption mode. The former is favorable to the formation of H2O2, while the latter is correlated to the dissociation of O2. 3 Overview of SACs The catalytic efficiency of the catalyst is the key to improve energy conversion efficiency. The emergence of SACs showed different activity and stability from traditionally supported catalysts, which greatly promoted the development of nano-catalysts. This part firstly introduces the concept of SACs and the development history of preparing SACs based on MOFs. Secondly, typical characterization techniques of SACs are introduced, and the microstructure of SACs is described. Thirdly, the microstructure and electrochemical performance of SACs are linked together to explore the underlying correlation between structural features and performances of catalysts. 3.1 The concept and development history of SACs As one of the limiting conditions of supported catalysts, the high atomic utilization efficiency and excellent catalytic activity of SACs have attracted extensive attention in recent years. That is, metals exist in various supports in the form of atoms (e.g., one-dimensional (1D), two-dimensional (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) materials), and the single metal atoms are used as the active centers for the catalytic reaction [94–99]. The metal center in SACs is not a zero-valent metal atom, but one with some charges, with the main difference of electronegativity between the metal-centered atom and the surrounding coordination atom. As a result, it leads to the process of electron transfer [100–102]. Its distinctive coordination environment provides the possibility for exploring the catalytic mechanism [97,103–105]. The preparation methods of SACs are mainly divided into the following two categories: 1) Bottom-up strategy [2,28,105–112]: The metal precursors undergo adsorption and reduction; then they are finally captured by vacancies on the support. It mainly includes the following methods: wet chemical method (ion exchange method, coprecipitation method, impregnation method, and photochemical method), galvanic replacement method, electrochemical dealloying method, mass soft-landing method, and atomic layer deposition (ALD); 2) Top-down strategy [105,113,114]: Convert metal nanoparticles (M−NPs) or bulk metals into SACs through heat treatment. It mainly includes the following methods: atom capture method at high temperatures. Since Zhang and co-workers demonstrated the novel concept, “single-atom electrocatalyst”, the 2010s has witnessed the rapid development of SACs within the discipline of catalysis [46]. It spreads a novel spectrum for the design and synthesis of high-performance catalysts. As popular materials, MOFs offer great potential in the synthesis of SACs, as of their unique 3D structure that provides many merits. Fig. 4 mainly summarizes the development history of SACs based on MOFs. In 2016, Yin et al. obtained Co-SAS/N-C catalyst with metal loading up to 4 wt% by pyrolyzing the cobalt-doped MOF structure, providing guidance for the preparation of TM-SACs using MOFs [115]. In 2018, Xing and co-workers prepared Fe-N-C SACs via the micropore confinement strategy [116]. In 2018, Li’s group observed the transformation of noble-metal NPs loaded on nitrogen-doped carbon (NC) supports into thermally stable single atoms at high temperatures [28]. In 2019, Wu’s group used NC produced from ZIF-8 as the main body for adsorbing iron ions, and explained the temperature-programmed formation mechanism of the FeN4 active site [117]. In addition, he used the two-step strategy of manganese-doped MOFs and post-adsorption to prepare Mn-NC with high-density single-atom active sites. It provides a novel strategy to expand the metal loading of SACs [118]. Shang et al. prepared the sulfur-doped S-Cu-ISA/SNC catalyst via cavity confinement strategy towards controlled synthesis and performance regulation of SACs [119]. In 2021, Su and co-workers achieved an efficient hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) by introducing atomically dispersed Ru into the MOFs [120]. Later on, the preparation methods and characterization techniques of SACs are becoming increasingly important in the field of energy conversion. How to accurately characterize SACs has become one of the challenging issues for their further development. More advanced characterization techniques are appearing, which opens a new door to explore and apply SACs. 3.2 Characterization of SACs Synthesis, characterization and performance of catalysts are three important and joint branches in the investigation of catalysts. The characterization of catalysts lies at analyzing their structures with the assistance of advanced scientific instruments, so as to configure the correlation between the intrinsic activity and structural feature. Thus, it further explores the catalytic reaction mechanism. It is difficult to characterize the presence and distribution of metal atoms in SACs due to the small size of metals. Therefore, both qualitative and quantitative analyses of SACs are the keys to the development of SACs. 3.2.1 Electron microscopy related techniques After a long history of development, electron microscopy is a crucial route for scientific clarification. The spherical aberration-corrected transmission electron microscope (TEM) has provided lots of valuable information for pinpointing SACs, with the assistance of sub-angstrom spatial resolution. As a consequence, it reveals the active center of the SACs [121–124] and provides the possibility of exploring their surface terminal states. The characterization of SACs by spherical aberration-corrected TEM is mainly rooted from the atomic number difference of different elements, i.e., Z-contrast, where the intensities of different elements in an image are approximately proportional to the atomic number square [125,126]. With a large difference in atomic numbers for transition metals and carbon elements, we can clearly identify the distribution of single metal atoms in a scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) image. The principle of electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) applies incident electrons to induce electron ionization in the targeting material, as well as excitation and oscillation of electrons in the valence band. It results in inelastic scattering and partial energy loss. The lost energy is correlated to some physical and chemical information of atoms in materials [127,128]. Thus, EELS enables accurately determining the fine structure of metal atoms. Combining EELS and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) can fingerprint accurately the elemental distribution of materials to ultimately assist phase identification for structural analysis. Ao et al. proved that iron elements exist in FeAC@FeSA-N-C as ultrafine nanoclusters and individual atoms through high angle annular dark-field STEM (HAADF-STEM) measurements (Fig. 5 a) [74]. In the image, green circles represent ultrafine nanoclusters and red circles denote single iron atoms. Metal atoms, as demonstrated by EDS, are highly dispersed into the whole carbon support. Wu’s group proved the existence of single cobalt atoms and Co-N coordination structures by using HAADF-STEM images and EELS (Fig. 5b) [75]. Meanwhile, EDS proved that single cobalt atoms were uniformly distributed within the carbon supports. Shao and co-workers also proved the existence of single cobalt atoms and Co-N coordination structure in the same way (Fig. 5c) [129]. Wu and co-workers also successfully confirmed the existence of individual manganese atoms and the construction of Mn-N coordination structure by using HAADF-STEM image and EELS (Fig. 5d) [118]. The use of spherical aberration-corrected TEM makes it possible to directly observe single atoms, facilitating synthesis and optimization of SACs. Exploring the relationship between catalyst structure and performance at the atomic scale can assist us to deeply pinpoint the mechanism and kinetics of the catalytic reaction, towards the improvement of the available catalysts and the development of new catalysts. 3.2.2 Spectroscopy related techniques 3.2.2.1 XAFS (XANES/EXAFS) X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) method, as an analysis method of synchrotron radiation, is an important research method to configure electronic and geometric structures of materials (the type, number and space position of atoms) [130–133]. According to the difference of photoelectron energy, it is mainly divided into two parts: XANES (X-ray absorption near edge structure) and EXAFS (extended X-ray absorption fine structure). XAFS is one of the most advantageous means to characterize SACs where both XANES and EXAFS play important roles. XANES uses the intensity of the white line peak to evaluate the valence states of single metal atoms. EXAFS can afford the coordination information and structural information of the metal atoms. By combining with DFT calculation, the structural information (coordination number, bond length, bond angle, arrangement pattern) of the active sites can be accurately obtained. XAFS provides sufficient evidence for the catalytic activity centers of SACs and greatly promotes their development. The effective combination of XAFS and spherical aberration-corrected electron microscope provides an important basis for confirming the geometric structure and electronic structure of individual atoms. Fig. 6 (a) shows the XANES and EXAFS spectrum of FeAC@FeSA-N-C to demonstrate the electronic and geometric structures. Ao et al. used XANES to confirm the existence form of iron atoms. Using the K-edge near-edge absorption threshold of Fe between Fe2O3 and Fe foil. Thus, they confirm that the valence state of Fe is 0∼+3 [74]. In the front peak region, FeAC@FeSA-N-C and FeSA-N-C have weak peaks at ∼7113 eV, proving that the coordination structure around iron atoms is close to a plane-symmetric structure, similar to the FeN4 structure in FePc. In the FT-EXAFS spectrum, the main peak is located at ∼1.5 Å. Thus, there is a Fe-N(O) scattering path. In FeAC@FeSA-N-C, the Fe-Fe peak is not obvious at ∼4.4 Å, indicating that iron elements take place as ultrafine nanoclusters and single atoms. Combined with EXAFS fitting, it is quantitatively revealed that iron atoms in the catalyst exist as ultrafine nanoclusters and FeN4 coordination structures. Fig. 6(b) shows the XANES and EXAFS spectrum of Co(mIm)–NC(1.0) to explore the electronic and geometric structures of the active cobalt center of SACs. Shao and co-workers also used the K-edge absorption threshold of Co in Co(mIm)–NC(1.0) located between Co0 foil and CoIIO and similar to CoIIO, demonstrating that the valence state of cobalt is +2 [129]. The peak strength of Co(mIm)–NC(1.0) is higher than that of octahedral Co(NO3)2·6H2O and CoPc with symmetrical structure in the edge peak region of 7708–7710 eV. In FT-EXAFS, the main peak appears at ∼1.4 Å, corresponding to the Co-N coordination path. The Co-Co coordination path has no peak, proving that cobalt atoms exist in Co(mIm)–NC(1.0) with Co-N coordination structure. Combining the EXAFS fitting curve with theoretical simulations, it was found that Co(mIm)–NC(1.0) is similar to the coordination environment of porphyrin with microporous structure, that is the coordination structure of non-planar CoN4C12 (Fig. 6c and d). The above data fully prove that the single cobalt atoms are highly dispersed in Co(mIm)–NC(1.0) with the CoN4 coordination structures. In addition, operando XAFS can effectively observe the change in the fine structure (electronic and geometric structures) of the metal active site during the catalytic process, which has a profound significance to reveal the catalytic mechanism. Liu et al. discovered the dynamic migration behavior of single copper atoms on the surface of Au-NPs driven by an electric field through in-situ synchrotron radiation (Fig. 7 a) [134]. In operando XANES, with increasing reduction potential, the white line peak of Au L3-edge gradually rises, while the white line peak of Cu K-edge decreases, indicating that electron transfer from Au to Cu has occurred in the single-atom alloy. From the fitting results of operando EXAFS, it is concluded that the coordination structure of Cu-Au has changed from five- to eight-coordination, indicating that the Cu atom has migrated from the corner position of the Au-NPs to the first layer of the (100) crystal plane. After the reaction was over, it returned to the starting position. This discovery is helpful to further explore the mechanism of surface structure and recombination of nano-catalysts. Yao and co-workers used in-situ synchrotron radiation again to discover the catalytic kinetic behavior of near free evolution of Pt-based SACs (Fig. 7b) [135]. The white line peak intensity of operando Pt L3-edge XANES decreased, indicating that its valence state decreased and the interaction between Pt and the CN support weakened. The operando EXAFS fitting data showed that the coordination number of Pt1-C/N changed from four- to two-coordination, and then Pt was closer to a free atom. Combined with theoretical calculations, the d-band structure of Pt atoms of this type is optimized, which is conducive to the adsorption of active sites and reactive species, and has improved HER performance in the electrolyte of full pH. 3.2.2.2 The other way The characterization of SACs has gradually matured. In addition, the introduction of other testing techniques and in-situ techniques, such as Mössbauer spectrum, infrared spectrum, operando Raman spectrum and operando diffuse reflectance infrared fourier trans-form spectroscopy (DRIFTS), have helped to accurately characterize SACs and explore the catalytic mechanism [136–139]. These characterization techniques confirmed the existence of SACs from different angles and formed a complete SACs characterization system. The infrared spectrum is widely used in catalysis to explore the intermediates and active sites in the catalytic process through the interaction between adsorbed molecules and supports. The symmetrical and asymmetric stretching vibrations of the intermediate species formed by the linear adsorption of the probe molecules on the single metal atom are presented in the form of spectral peaks to prove the existence of single atoms [138]. Christopher’s group used the strong adsorption of single Rh atom sites with CO probe molecules. The symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of the Rh(CO)2 species correspond to the peaks at 2097 and 2028 cm−1, and these species exist in the Rhiso site on the TiO2 support [143–146]. In Fig. 8 (a), the species formed by CO probe molecules and Rh-NPs correspond to the peaks at 2068 and 1860 cm−1. By increasing the loading capacity of Rh atom in TiO2 support, Rh atom gradually changes from single atoms to Rh-NPs and nanoclusters, which modifies the adsorption mode with CO probe molecule and results in the change of peak position. Ye et al. used LT-FTIR to confirm the adsorption modes of different types of Fe clusters on oxygen molecules [140]. In Fig. 8(b), the peaks at 1200–1350 and 800–1000 cm−1 correspond to the vibrations of the superoxo-like and peroxo-like O2 species, respectively [147]. Fe1-N-C mainly adsorbed oxygen molecules in superoxo-like adsorption mode, while Fe2-N-C and Fe3-N-C mainly adsorbed oxygen molecules in peroxo-like adsorption mode. Experiments combined with theoretical calculations confirm that the adsorption way between O2 and active sites depends on the amount of iron atoms at the active sites. Piccolo and co-workers used operando DRIFTS to monitor the changes in the CO oxidation process of platinum atoms loaded on alumina (Fig. 8c) [141]. The main peak at 2106–2100 cm−1 corresponds to CO molecule linearly adsorbed on single Pt1 m+ site, and the shoulder peak at 2090–2070 cm−1 corresponds to partially oxidized Pt nanoclusters [148]. The whole process shows that single Pt atom is difficult to adsorb CO and O2 molecules concurrently. At low temperatures, O2 tends to adsorb on Pt atoms. At high temperatures, CO tends to adsorb on clusters formed by Pt atoms. Tait and co-workers used the CO adsorption behavior on Pt atoms to perform operando DRIFTS (Fig. 8d) [142]. Pt-PDO/TiO2 has an adsorption peak with a wavenumber larger than 2100 cm−1 at 30 °C, which corresponds to the adsorption of CO and Pt atoms. Pt-NPs/TiO2 has an adsorption peak with wavenumber of 2060 cm−1 at 30 °C, which corresponds to the adsorption of CO and Pt-NPs. When the temperature rises to 50 °C, the adsorption peak of Pt-PDO/TiO2 increases. This phenomenon indicates that the coordination structure of Pt has changed, which makes the platinum site more easily adsorbed with CO molecule. Mössbauer spectrum can prove the existence of high-loading single metal atoms and the coordination environment of metal active centers. Xiao et al. applied the 57Fe Mössbauer spectrum to analyze the coordination environment of single iron atoms (Fig. 9 a) [116]. 57Fe Mössbauer spectrum fits into three parts: D1 and D2 correspond to the low-spin and medium-spin states of Fe2+ in the square plane Fe2+-N4 coordination structure, respectively. A singlet with a velocity approaching zero represents r-Fe. The results of the quantitative spectroscopic analysis showed that the contents of D1, D2 and crystalline iron species were 30.1%, 64.4% and 5.4%, respectively, indicating that the single-atom active site FeN4 was dominant. High-density FeN4 active site affords excellent ORR activity. Li et al. characterized FeCl2-NC-Air by in-situ Mössbauer spectrum at low temperatures (5 K) (Fig. 9b) [149]. The results showed that the D1 and D2 parts correspond to Fe1(III)-N4-O2 and Fe1(II)-N4 respectively, confirming the existence of iron species. Operando Raman spectrum can effectively detect adsorbed species at the metal active sites during the reaction process. Li and co-workers constructed Pb-based SACs model catalysts with different electronic structures and coordination structures (Fig. 9c) [150]. The Raman peak at 1083 cm−1 corresponds to the reaction intermediate species of O2-adsorption. The shell-isolated nanoparticles-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SHINERS) had surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) on Au, Ag, Cu noble-metal species with a specific structure, which can effectively detect the reaction dynamic process of SACs. Taking advantage of the different adsorption behavior of phenyl isocyanide (PIC) probe molecules to single Pb atoms and Pb-NPs, SHINERS can effectively detect the change process of Pb during the reaction (single atoms to M−NPs). In addition, single Pb atoms are more likely to be distributed on the surface of TiO2 compared to Al2O3. Liu’s group analyzed the electronic structure and geometric structure of Ni in the reaction process by the operando Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 9d) [151]. Raman peaks at 182 and 244 cm−1 are divided into corresponding isoindole deformation and Ni-N vibration. In an Ar atmosphere, when the applied potential increases to 0.57 V, the vibration peak of Ni-N gradually moves to the direction of low wavenumbers. This indicates that the coordination structure of Ni-N gradually weakens. After the addition of CO2, the vibration peak of Ni-N gradually recovered to the initial energy position. These characterizations confirmed the dynamic change process of Ni-N during the CO2RR process, and Ni2+ formed during the reaction process showed good CO2RR activity. Among the techniques for characterizing SACs, HAADF-STEM images and EXAFS are undoubtedly the most advantageous means to verify SACs. However, these technologies have certain disadvantages. HAADF-STEM images can only represent the local information of the sample, but cannot represent the overall information of the sample. EXAFS characterizes the overall information of the sample, but its sensitivity is not enough to distinguish between single atoms and nanoclusters [152,153]. This is not conducive to the further study of the catalytic reaction mechanism. To overcome the errors caused by such limitations, HAADF-STEM can be utilized more carefully and the error of EXAFS fitting data can be further reduced. For other characterization methods, only part of single metal atoms can be effectively detected, and the generalization of most metal atoms cannot be achieved. Therefore, the development of new characterization methods to perform more reasonable characterization and detection of SACs has become an arduous task at present. The introduction of advanced in-situ characterization techniques is helpful to monitor the changes of the electronic and geometric structures of single-atom sites in the catalytic process, and is conducive to the in-depth discussion of the catalytic reaction mechanism. The development of new characterization techniques has important research significance for the synthesis and preparation of SACs, microstructural analysis, and catalytic mechanistic exploration. 3.3 Application of SACs in ORR As the key reaction of many important energy conversion devices, the catalytic efficiency of ORR often determines the reaction efficiency of the overall device. Exploring ORR catalysts abundant with high activity, long durability and low cost is one of the challenging issues that need to be addressed at present [79,85,107]. To measure the performance of electrocatalysts, commercial Pt/C is treated as the common benchmark catalyst for ORR. The commonly used performance parameters mainly include the following categories: initial potential (E onset), half-wave potential (E 1/2), Tafel slope, cyclic stability, limiting current density (J L), and kinetic current density (J K). Xing’s group used the RRDE technique for the ORR testing [116]. As shown in the LSV data (Fig. 10 a), the Fe-N-C-950 catalyst shows a corrected E onset (0.92 V) and E 1/2 (0.78 V) in 0.1 M HClO4. According to the K-L equation, the LSV curves at a variety of rotational speeds prove that the dominant four-electron pathway is consistent with the RRDE results in Fig. 10(b). The low Tafel slope of the Fe-N-C-950 catalyst demonstrates its excellent ORR performance in Fig. 10(c). After 10,000 cycles of cycle stability test, the E 1/2 is negatively shifted by 12 mV, showing excellent cycle stability in Fig. 10(d). Currently, a major challenge is the practical application of SACs in battery systems, including lithium-sulfur batteries, metal-air batteries, fuel cells and other energy storage batteries [155–160]. In order to achieve the high-rate and high-capacity performance of these battery systems, TM-SACs must have high catalytic activity and high stability to overcome the complex practical operating environment. Wu and co-workers adjusted the doping amount of cobalt in the ZIFs and pyrolysis temperature, proving that 20Co-NC-1100 catalyst has the optimal ORR activity (Fig. 10e and f) [154]. In the polarization curve of the H2/O2 fuel cell, the open-circuit voltage is as high as 0.95 V, well comparable to the conventional ketjenblack (KJ)-supported PANI-derived Fe catalyst (PANI-Fe-KJ). The highest power density reached 0.56 W cm−2. The polarization curve of the H2/air fuel cell also shows that its performance is superior to PANI-Fe-KJ and PANI-Co-KJ, and the maximum power is 0.28 W cm−2. This indicates that the catalyst has an optimum good three-phase interface and catalytic mass transfer process. The performance durability test of the fuel cell was performed at 0.7 V for 100 h. After 100 h, there will be a loss of ∼60 mV, showing excellent stability at such a high voltage (0.7 V). In addition, using similar principles, zinc-air batteries are often used to test the performance of catalysts. In conclusion, after years of development, the excellent ORR performance of TM-SACs has been greatly improved, and it has become the most potential substitute for replacing noble-metal catalysts. The biggest challenge facing SACs in fuel cells is their poor stability, which leads to the rapid degradation of the overall battery performance [104,114,161]. It may mainly come from the following three reasons: 1) In a strong oxidation environment, metal active sites may dissolve, and the carbon support will also have a certain degree of corrosion. 2) The collapse of the three-phase interface and water flooding in the cathode also produce certain resistance to the proton and oxygen molecule transport. 3) Some highly oxidizing species produced during the reaction attack the active sites and structures of the catalysts. In order to improve the practical application of SACs in fuel cells, new strategies have been developed to overcome these problems. These strategies mainly include the following points: 1) Effectively avoiding the generation of strong oxidizing species. 2) Enhancing the interaction between the metal and the support. 3) Increasing the stability of the support. 4) Reducing water flooding. 4 Several strategies for preparing TM-SACs based on MOFs The rational design and controllable formation of SACs are important tasks in the emerging field of catalysis. SACs have a high specific surface energy, resulting in poor stability during the preparation and the catalytic reaction. Obviously, how to overcome these problems is the only way to accelerate the development of SACs [162]. Since single atoms are prone to agglomeration during the preparation, the choice of support material is particularly important for the formation of SACs. And the support will also affect the electron transport and material transport in the catalytic reaction. Due to the unique structure and spatial structure, MOFs are good precursors for preparing SACs. In this part, five strategies for preparing TM-SACs using MOFs are summarized in detail, and the correlation between structural features and performance is explored for SACs. All of these strategies focus on how to protect transition-metallic atoms from agglomeration during the pyrolysis process. There are some differences in protection mechanisms due to the different ways of modifying MOFs. Based on the differences in protection mechanisms, this part divides them into the following five strategies: 1) Surface confinement strategy: The “space fence” effect of the sacrificial metal atom is used to make the doped transition-metallic atom produce a certain spatial distance, so as to avoid the accumulation of metal atoms in the pyrolysis process. 2) Cavity confinement strategy: Using the advantages of the unique cavity structure of the MOFs, the metal precursor is encapsulated. This encapsulation effect can minimize the accumulation of metal precursors during the pyrolysis process. 3) Outer protection strategy: Some protective measures are taken on the outer layer of the MOFs to avoid the collapse of the structure and the aggregation of metal atoms during the pyrolysis process. 4) Phase diffusion strategy: Metal atoms diffuse at high temperatures, and are captured and reduced in the support. 5) Dual-template strategy: By introducing an external template, the MOFs template is restricted and protected, which can effectively prevent the aggregation of single atoms. 4.1 Surface confinement strategy As MOFs afford highly atomically dispersed metal sites, qualified as are promising precursors or templates for the preparation of SACs [163–166]. By using the “space fence” effect of sacrificial metals (SMs), the distance of transition-metallic sites enables being adjusted, which can bypass the aggregation of doped transition-metallic atoms at high temperatures. Because SMs have relatively low melting points, they can be vaporized by high-temperature pyrolysis [84,119,167–169]. According to the amount of doped transition metals, they can be mainly divided into the following categories: 1) Single-metal doping; 2) Dual/multi-metal doping. 4.1.1 Single-metal doping TM-SACs formed by introducing single transition-metallic atoms into the MOFs have high catalytic activity and stability. For single-metal doping, according to the different types of elements, it can be divided into the following types: iron doping, cobalt doping, chromium doping, and manganese doping. As a 3d transition-group metal, the 3d shell of Fe is not filled and the valence electron position is 3d6. Because of its special d-band electronic structure, activity, stability and selectivity are expected. The particle size of the catalyst affects the catalyst activity. Wu’s group formed the Fe-doped ZIF-8 precursor by in-situ iron doping during the synthesis of ZIF-8 (Fig. 11 a) [128]. The precursor size is regulated by adjusting the concentration of metal salts and ligands. In the synthesis of ZIFs, iron ions partially replace zinc ions, thus forming the coexisting ZnN4 and FeN4 complexes. Through high-temperature pyrolysis, the FeN4 complex is transformed into the FeN4 active sites embedded in NC via carbon reduction. Zinc vaporized easily at high temperatures, facilitating the spatial isolation of iron atoms and the formation of porous carbon structures. It is found that with the decrease of the precursor size, its specific surface area gradually increases whereas its performance gradually increases, due possibly to the increase of active site density. After reaching the critical size, the specific surface area and catalytic performance decrease, due to a large number of small particles gathering, resulting in less exposed active sites. When the critical size is 50 nm, the FeSA-N-C catalyst shows the optimum ORR activity in acidic media, and the E 1/2 reaches 0.85 V. It merely loses 20 mV after 10,000 potential cycles, showing excellent stability. The necessary conditions for the formation of SACs are to control the concentration of metal atoms and the pyrolysis conditions. Fig. 11(b) illustrates the influence of metal doping amount on the formation of SACs. Wu and co-workers adjusted the amount of iron doping in ZIF-8, so that iron is highly dispersed in the form of atoms in the graphitized carbon support after carbonization [170]. It was found that the correlation between ORR activity and the iron doping content shows a “fire line” curve. Too low iron doping amount leads to an insufficient density of active sites, whereas too high iron doping amount causes iron atoms to form nano-clusters and reduce amounts of active sites. The pyrolysis temperature also acts as the formation of SACs. Li et al. explained the formation mechanism of FeN4 active sites by adsorbing amounts of iron ions in the NC skeleton obtained after carbonization of ZIF-8 and regulating the pyrolysis temperature (Fig. 11c) [117]. By controlling the pyrolysis temperature at 400, 700 and 1100 °C, it proves that 700 °C is the thermal activation temperature for the formation of the optimal FeN4 structure, while the higher temperature (1100 °C) will result in the destruction of carbon structure and the FeN X active sites. In addition, temperature also has effects on the stability of the catalyst. The lower temperature is conducive to the formation of stable FeN4 coordination structure with short bond length and symmetric coordination. Although the higher temperature makes the carbon structure more stable and the graphitization degree is higher, it will lose partial nitrogen source and damage the coordination structure, which is not conducive to the improvement of stability. DFT calculations show that the shortening of Fe-N leads to a positive shift in the 3d orbital of iron atoms and more charge transfer from iron atoms to surrounding nitrogen atoms. Changes in temperature will regulate the electronic structure of the active site, which is conducive to the adsorption of oxygen molecules and active sites and the breaking of O-O bond. In addition to the ZIFs, Jiang’s group also used porphyrin MOFs to synthesize FeSA-N-C catalyst. They used the mixed ligand for the preparation of a series of 1D mesoporous channel precursors with the same structure by modulating the ratio of Fe-TCPP and H2-TCPP ligands [171]. The spatial barrier effect of H2-TCPP ligand enlarges the distance between neighboring Fe-TCPP, which effectively avoids the aggregation of Fe atoms in pyrolysis. FeSA-N-C catalyst has high ORR activity and stability under acidic and alkaline media due to its single FeN4 active site, hierarchical porous structure and high electrical conductivity. The hierarchical porous structure greatly promotes the mass transfer process and accommodates more active sites, which improves the accessibility of active sites and thereof the catalytic activity. Besides Zn, Cd can also be used as a sacrificial metal to effectively prepare SACs due to its lower boiling point (140 °C lower than Zn) and its capability to bind to various MOFs. Yang and co-workers used Cd sources as SMs and 1, 4-diazabicyclio [2.2.2] octane (DABCO) as a nitrogen-containing ligand (cage tertiary amine) to form MOFs with terephthalic acid (TPA) and iron-driven precursors. The highly active Fe-based SACs were prepared at low temperatures [172]. This method can prepare highly active SACs at lower temperatures, increase the selectivity of SMs, effectively reduce energy consumption and largely avoid aggregation of single atoms. Cobalt has an unfilled 3d shell electronic structure similar to iron element, and the ORR activity is second only to Fe. Similar to the principle of iron doping, using the spatial isolation effect of Zn, the Co-doped ZIFs also realize Co-based SACs by tuning the cobalt doping amount and the pyrolysis temperature. Li and co-workers mixed zinc and cobalt salts in proportion and assembled them with dimethylimidazole ligands to form a 3D network structure (Fig. 11d) [115]. Its single-atom loading is up to 4 wt%. In the alkaline media, Co SAs/N-C (800) exhibited excellent ORR activity and good stability. Its E 1/2 is 0.881 V, which exceeds the commercial Pt/C (0.811 V). Wang et al. also made a series of adjustments to the cobalt doping amount in ZIFs and pyrolysis temperature [154]. The relationship between ORR activity and cobalt doping amount presents a “volcano plot” correlation. The size of M−NPs affects the catalytic activity. Deng’s group achieved spatial separation of cobalt species at an atomic scale by regulating the molar ratio of Zn/Co in ZIFs [173]. The influence of metal particle size on the catalytic activity was investigated by comparing the differences in the catalytic activity of M−NPs, atomic clusters and single atoms. The Co-based SACs have the highest atom utilization efficiency and catalytic active sites, facilitating the reaction progress. High conductivity, large surface area and hierarchical porous structure of the carbon support facilitate the improvement of catalytic activity. Inspired by the high catalytic activity of binuclear cobalt macrocyclic compounds (porphyrins in the respiratory system) [174–176], the coordination structure of the binuclear metal center has also optimum ORR activity [177,178]. Using a similar method, Xing and co-workers successfully synthesized catalysts with Co2N5 coordination structure by adjusting the doping amount of Zn [168]. HAADF-STEM images found dual-atom sites with a Co-Co distance of 2.1–2.2 Å, combined with the new shortened Co-Co path (2.1 Å) in XAS to determine the Co2N5 coordination structure. In the alkaline media, its catalytic activity is ∼12 times higher than the traditional CoN4 coordination structure, and the E 1/2 in the acidic media reaches 0.80 V. This new coordination structure breaks the traditional recognition that the MN4 structure has the highest catalytic activity. Thus, it provides a new idea and direction for the construction of subsequent catalytic sites. On the basis of previous studies, Zhou et al. used the “balloon” effect to promote the gradual expansion and decomposition of the derived carbon layer by adjusting the pressure difference for both inside and outside the tubular furnace (Fig. 11e) [84]. This method promotes the formation of 3D graphene skeletons, in which cobalt atoms are highly dispersed. Compared with traditional pyrolysis, the formed 3D graphene skeleton has an optimum mesoporous structure and electrical conductivity, conducive to accommodate high-density active sites. In-situ TEM and DFT calculations were used to study the formation mechanism. The results show that the negative pressure can promote the selective cracking of the carbon layer and the evaporation of unstable atoms, thus effectively inducing the formation of carbon defects near the metal center and reducing the ORR overpotential. Co SAs/3D GF exhibited a high E onset (1.032 V) and E 1/2 (0.901 V) in a 0.1 M KOH solution. This strategy facilitates the preparation of SACs based on MOFs and a new idea for the structural design of catalysts. Cr and Mn have optimum ORR activities and can effectively avoid Fenton reaction. Fig. 12 (a) shows the preparation of catalyst by solvent-assisted surface integration strategy. Xing and co-workers used ZIF-8 as the precursor, and took advantage of the unique micropore structure of ZIF-8 and the hydration of CrCl3, adsorbed CrCl3 into the micropore of ZIF-8 through the double-solvent method. After pyrolysis, they became Cr-based SACs with Cr-N4 coordination structures [167]. The prepared catalyst showed improved ORR performance in an acidic medium. The E 1/2 reached 0.773 V, and showed an excellent stability. The binding energy of the Cr-N4 site with oxygen molecule is obviously weakened, and it has improved intrinsic activity, which is beneficial to the ORR reaction. Both Mn and Fe are in the fourth period and have a 3d54s2 outer electronic layer arrangement structure. Since the adsorption energy of Mn-N-C on OH* is less than that of Fe-N-C, it shows strong intrinsic activity [180]. Due to the weak activity between Mn and H2O2, the Fenton reaction can be ignored, especially in acidic media, which shows improved ORR activity and stability [181–183]. Wu’s group prepared Mn-N-C catalysts with highly dispersed manganese atoms through a two-step method of doping and post-adsorption (Fig. 12b) [118]. The manganese doping amount has effects on the size of the carbon support and the degree of graphitization. DFT calculations confirmed that MnN4C12 active site has the best binding energy for reactive species (such as O2*, OOH*, and H2O*), which is conducive to the breaking of O-O bonds and the occurrence of four-electron reaction pathways. The excellent activity of Mn-NC-second mainly comes from the high-density single-atom active sites and partially graphitized carbon support. This post-adsorption strategy inspires increasing the metal loading of SACs. The traditional synthesis methods of MOFs mostly use methanol, N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) as the representative organic solvent, which is not friendly to the environment. As a good substitute for organic solvent, water solvent has the characteristics of high synthesis efficiency, low cost and environmental friendliness. However, manganese salts are easily hydrolyzed in an aqueous solution to form oxides/clusters. Fig. 12(c) shows the acid-assisted synthesis of MOFs and secondary pyrolysis to prepare Mn-based SACs. Xu and co-workers replaced the traditional organic solvent with an aqueous solution and added HCl in the synthesis process of Mn doping ZIF-8 to effectively slow down the hydrolysis process of manganese [179]. Subsequently, SACs with high-density MnN4 coordination structures are formed by secondary adsorption of metal ions and pyrolysis. At 1.0 bar H2-air, the peak power density of the catalyst is 0.39 W cm−2, and the performance of the catalyst is superior to most ORR catalysts without platinum group materials (PGM). The high intrinsic activity of MnN4 active sites and highly curved graphitic carbon structure facilitate improving ORR activity and stability. In transition metals, the ORR activity of Ni and Cu is not as good as that of Fe and Co, but they show an excellent CO2RR activity [110,169,184–186]. It was found that SACs with M−N−C structure were prepared by doping MOFs with Ni and Cu, showing high conversion efficiency and CO Faraday efficiency. The excellent activity of TM-SACs is mainly derived from the unique electronic structure of transition metal. Different transition metals exhibit different ORR activities due to their different electronic structures. Fe-based SACs have high catalytic activity, stability and selectivity in the alkaline system. However, the lack of activity and stability in the acidic system is mainly due to the Fenton reaction, which cannot replace noble-metal catalyst in practical fuel cells. In addition, iron species tend to agglomerate during the pyrolysis process, resulting in some inactive metal species, such as Fe-NPs and Fe3C species [187,188]. Cobalt has a similar electronic structure to iron and its ORR activity is second only to that of Fe. Fenton reaction does not occur easily in Co-based SACs. In the alkaline condition, Co-based SACs show excellent ORR performance. However, ORR activity is not particularly ideal in acidic media due to the introduction of some species (e.g., metal particles, oxides, carbides, and nitrides) that are not conducive to increasing activity [70,189]. The excellent electronic structure of manganese metal makes it a good application prospect in ORR. The adsorption energy of Mn-N X for OH* is smaller than that of Fe-N X structure, which leads to its strong ORR intrinsic activity. Due to the weak interaction between Mn and H2O2, the Fenton reaction can be neglected in an acidic media, resulting in improved ORR activity and stability. For carbon-based catalysts, the introduction of manganese can also increase the graphitization degree of the support, which is beneficial to the electron transfer process. However, manganese salts are prone to hydrolyze in an aqueous solution to form oxides/clusters, which is not conducive to the formation of SACs. The ORR intrinsic activity of Ni and Cu is not as good as that of Fe and Co, but they show good CO2RR activity. Studies have shown that ORR activity can be enhanced by constructing dual-atom catalysts, such as NiFe, NiCo, ZnCu. For transition-metallic materials, the Fenton reaction hardly occurs due to the excellent ORR activity of Mn in both acidic and alkaline systems, which can adapt to the complex working environment of fuel cells. In addition, the cost of Mn is lower than that of noble-metal catalyst, so it has a wide range of industrial application prospects. 4.1.2 Dual/multi-metal doping Different from single-metal doping, dual/multi-metal doping uses the synergistic catalysis between different metals to improve the catalytic activity [190–192]. Adzic and co-workers found that the correlation between the ORR activity and the adsorption strength of intermediate products and active sites showed a “volcano plot” curve [193]. If dual-metal or multi-metal is introduced, the synergistic catalytic effect between metals can be utilized to optimize the electronic structure of active sites, so as to achieve the optimal adsorption strength between the active sites and oxygen-containing intermediates [194–198]. Wei et al. used the heteroatom modulator strategy to prepare MOFs with an aromatic ring array structure (Fig. 13 a). During the synthesis process, zinc and cobalt ions were introduced to realize the regulation of iron atoms from nanoclusters to dual atoms, and also realize the high dispersion of single cobalt atoms [199]. This unique MOF structure is transformed into a NC structure by heat treatment, which is an ideal support for stabilizing metal species. The ultrafine nanoclusters have an excellent electronic structure, which enables the catalysts to exhibit improved ORR and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) activities. This strategy facilitates the design and preparation of ultrafine metal cluster nano-catalysts with excellent catalytic activity. There are controversies over the issue of the catalytic activity of metal nanoclusters and single metal atoms [196,202–204]. Some believe that SACs have higher catalytic activity on account of their merits such as high atomic utilization efficiency, particular electronic structure, quantum size effect, unsaturated active site and well-defined reaction mechanism [105,205]. However, nanoclusters will greatly reduce the utilization efficiency of single atoms, which is not conducive to the improvement of activity. In the M−N−C catalyst, some people believe that M−NPs are favorable to ORR activity in the alkaline media, but unfavorable under the acid condition [206–208]. If they directly contact with the electrolyte, they may react and lead to corrosion. If they are surrounded by carbon shells, they can effectively prevent their corrosion and contribute to the electronegativity change of the surrounding carbon. Through theoretical calculations, it was found that M−NPs have a positive effect on the surrounding MN4 coordination structure, and the synergistic effect between them can effectively improve the adsorption strength between oxygen reduction intermediates and active sites, and enhance the intrinsic catalytic activity of metal centers [128,207,209–212]. Sun and co-workers added an amount of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate, zinc nitrate hexahydrate and ferrous sulfate heptahydrate in the synthesis process of ZIFs in proportions, and prepared the FeCo-SAs-N-C catalyst with the coexistence of M−NPs and single atoms through pyrolysis (Fig. 13b) [200]. The existence of single atoms and M−NPs was confirmed by using synchrotron radiation technology and spherical aberration electron microscopy. DFT calculation confirmed the synergistic catalytic effect of M−NPs and MN4 sites. M−NPs can increase the charge density of the surrounding FeN4 sites, which is conducive to the adsorption and dissociation of oxygen molecules, thereby inhibiting the formation of reactive oxygen species (ROS). This composite structure facilitates the four-electron reaction pathway in an acidic condition. Therefore, it facilitates the construction of ORR active sites in an acid medium. The activity and stability of platinum-based catalysts can be significantly promoted by alloying and structure control. Liu’s group used ZIF-8 as the support to adsorb iron ions through the double-solvent method, and obtained FeSA-N-C catalyst after pyrolysis [201]. Then using it as a support, a highly ordered Pt3M (M: Fe and Zn) intermetallic compound structure PtA@FeSA-N-C was obtained through Pt deposition and alloying (Fig. 13d). The catalyst showed good catalytic activity and durability in acidic media, and the E 1/2 reached 0.923 V, and the activity almost did not decrease after 5000 cycles of stability tests. The NC support obtained after carbonization of ZIF-8 can fully expose more active sites and provide more favorable sites for the anchoring of Pt intermetallic compounds. The strong interaction among the stable and ordered Pt3M intermetallic structure and FeN4 active sites is beneficial to improve the stability and activity of the catalyst. DFT calculations confirmed that the Pt (100) crystal face optimized the electronic structure of the surrounding FeN4 active site (Fig. 13c). Since Pt is more electronegative than Fe, the charge is transferred from Fe atom to Pt atom. At this time, the positive charge density of Fe atom increases significantly, which is conducive to the four-electron reaction pathway. This alloying strategy also provides a good idea for improving ORR activity under acidic conditions. A variety of transition metals are introduced into the MOFs. The metals may exist as individual atoms, M−NPs, the coexistence of M−NPs and individual atoms and alloying. The synergistic catalytic effect of dual/multi-metal and the synergistic catalytic effect of M−NPs and single atoms in an acidic medium are beneficial to the improvement of catalytic activity. Introducing dual/multi-metal active centers into MOFs enables modifying the electronic and geometric structures of the active centers. As a consequence, it guides the subsequent design of catalyst structures and the exploration of surface terminal states. For the surface confine strategy, the introduction of doping metals into MOFs and the space confinement effect of SMs are beneficial to the formation of SACs after pyrolysis. Because of the special outermost electronic structure of the transition metal, the TM-SACs exhibits excellent ORR activity. The formed MN X active site has a distinctive coordination structure, which is helpful to mechanistic elucidation. However, there are some drawbacks to this strategy: 1) Doped metals are prone to aggregation. Although the presence of SMs can increase the distance between the metal atoms, this distance is not uniform. Some may be very far away, whereas others may be very close. It is difficult to achieve uniform dispersion of doped metals on the main body. Metal atoms that are very close are still prone to aggregation; 2) The complicated steps of pickling and secondary pyrolysis are needed. After in-situ doping and pyrolysis, the excess M−NPs are often removed by pickling, and sometimes secondary pyrolysis is needed to repair the carbon structure; 3) It is difficult to achieve a complete single atomization of doped metals, and the atomic utilization efficiency is low; 4) The coordination environment of different doped metals varies, and the generalization of the preparation strategy is challenging. 4.2 Cavity confinement strategy The cavity structure of MOFs can encapsulate a part of metal precursor molecules. For the ZIFs, ZIF-8 is a 3D space nanocage with a rhombic dodecahedron structure assembled by zinc ions and dimethylimidazole ligands [213–217]. Since ZIF-8 has a special cavity structure with an aperture of 3.4 Å and a cavity diameter of 11 Å, the metal-containing precursors can be encapsulated in the cavity of ZIF-8 to achieve spatial isolation of metal precursors and prevent aggregation in the pyrolysis process, so as to achieve a high dispersion of metal atoms [218,219]. After the carbonization process, the ZIF-8 structure becomes an NC skeleton, which provides the support for the metal active site. Common metal precursors fall into the following categories: 1) Metal inorganic compounds, such as metal salts and hydroxides; 2) Metal organic compounds, such as acetylacetone compounds and ferrocene; 3) Metal macrocyclic compounds, such as phthalocyanine, porphyrin, and phenanthroline. 4.2.1 Metal inorganic compounds Metal inorganic compounds, such as metal salts and metal hydroxides, have applications as their rich sources and low pollution to the environment. Since the valence state of Mn varies greatly from 0 to +7, it is easy to cause agglomeration in the pyrolysis process. Han et al. added manganese acetate containing manganese source in synthesis of ZIF-8 and in-situ encapsulated in the cage of ZIF-8, and prepared Mn-SAS/CN catalyst containing a large number of atomic dispersion MnN4 sites through pyrolysis (Fig. 14 a) [220]. Using Operando XAFS, it proved that the structure of MnN4 active site changes with the applied voltage (OHads-MnH+-N4 + e-→MnL+-N4 + OH–). MnL+-N4 as a catalytic center facilitates the electron transfer process. DFT calculation showed that MnL+-N4 structure tends to rapidly transfer electrons to OH* to form OH–, which is conducive to the improvement of ORR activity. The introduction of manganese source effectively formed amounts of MnN4 active sites and increased the graphitization degree of the support, making it exhibit good ORR activity and stability in 0.1 M KOH. Zinc and cobalt co-doped ZIFs were taken as the main body and encapsulated FeCl3 in the cavity by the double-solvent method (Fig. 14b) [221]. After carbonization, a carbon-based catalyst with cobalt and iron active sites was obtained. The existence of iron species can afford nitrogen-doped graphene, and also accelerate the decomposition of metal-imidazole-metal bonds, resulting in certain hollow structures. Experiments and theoretical calculations show that the Fe-Co dual-metal centers are favorable to the adsorption of oxygen molecules and the breaking of O=O bonds. The prepared catalyst exhibited improved ORR activity in an acidic system, and its E onset (1.06 vs. 1.03 V) and E 1/2 (0.863 vs. 0.858 V) are comparable to those of commercial Pt/C. Yang’s group used a similar method to encapsulate copper chloride in the cavity of ZIF-8, and then treated it with KOH to form Cu(OH)2@ZIF-8. After the pyrolysis, C-Cu(OH)2@ZIF-8-10%-1000 catalysts coexisting with Cu-NPs and Cu1N4 were obtained (Fig. 14c) [222]. The synergistic effect of Cu-NPs and Cu-N X sites renders the prepared catalyst with the improved ORR activity and CO2RR activity. In addition, the existence of the hollow structure greatly promotes the improvement of catalytic activity. 4.2.2 Metal organic compounds If the cavity structure of ZIF-8 is used to encapsulate metal precursors, its molecular size should be smaller than that of ZIF-8. Fig. 14(d) shows the use of the cavity structure of ZIF-8 to encapsulate iron acetylacetone to form Fe(acac)3@ZIF-8 composite products [67]. Li and co-workers used iron acetylacetone with a molecular diameter of ∼9.7 Å. After pyrolysis, the Fe-ISAs/CN catalyst exhibited improved ORR activity (E 1/2 = 0.900 V, J K = 37.83 mV cm−2 at 0.85 V). Besides, it has improved methanol tolerance and stability. The loading of Fe reaches 2.16 wt%. The high ORR activity is mainly derived from the high catalytic intrinsic activity and high electron transfer efficiency of single-atom iron sites. Experiments combined with theoretical calculations proved that the end-on adsorption of single-atom active sites and oxygen molecules is beneficial to the ORR. Shao’s group encapsulated cobalt acetylacetone in the micropores of the ZIF-8 structure, and then transformed Co(acac)3@ZIF-8 into Co(mIm)4@ZIF-8 by ligand exchange strategy (Fig. 14e) [129]. SACs with CoN4 coordination structure were obtained after pyrolysis. DFT calculations showed that the shortening of the Co-N bond length leads to good stability and demetallation resistance of the catalyst. Exploring the general preparation strategy of SACs to realize the efficient synthesis of catalysts is an urgent issue to be addressed. Li’s group also used ZIF-8 as the main body to encapsulate different types of acetylacetone precursors [184]. The resulting precursors were pyrolyzed so that the single atoms were highly dispersed on N-doped carbon supports (M1/CN, M = Pt, Ir, Pd, Ru, Mo, Ga, Cu, Ni and Mn). This strategy can be extended to a variety of 3d, 4p, 4d and 5d catalytic active elements (including but not limited to Pt, Pd, Ru, Mo, Ga, Cu, Ni and Mn), which has a profound impact. Except for the acetylacetone precursor, the ferrocene (Fc) molecule is 9.4 Å in diameter and has good solubility in methanol. Wang et al. successfully encapsulated Fc in the cavity structure of ZIF-8 [223]. By adjusting the doping amount of Fc, uniformly dispersed Fe-based SACs were prepared by pyrolysis. The E 1/2 of the prepared catalyst reached 0.904 V, superior to that of commercial Pt/C (0.837 V). The high specific surface area and ideal pore structure greatly facilitate the catalytic mass transfer process and provide plenty of space for the loading of the active sites. 4.2.3 Metal macrocyclic compounds Porphyrin (PP), phthalocyanine(Pc) and tetraphenylporphyrin(TPP) are some common macrocyclic metal chelates with clear molecular structures, which are favorable precursors for the synthesis of carbon-based catalysts [224]. The molecular size of cobalt phthalocyanine is 14.6 Å, and it cannot be encapsulated into the cavity structure of ZIF-8. Wang and co-workers made use of the Kirkendall effect. In the synthesis process of ZIF-8, FePc broke the cavity as well as the localized effect of micropores, forming hollow structures and amount of FeN4 active sites dominated by edges (Fig. 15 a) [225]. The Fe SAs-N/C-20 catalyst displayed improved ORR performance (E 1/2 = 0.915 V) in 0.1 M KOH, which was higher than that of commercial Pt/C (E 1/2 = 0.85 V) and the great mass of M−N−C catalysts. It has excellent stability and high metallic atom utilization efficiency (∼10 times improvement). DFT calculation showed that the defect structure at the gap edge is beneficial to regulate the electronic structure of the active sites. This structure can significantly reduce the ORR reaction barrier. The formed hierarchical porous structure can optimize the geometrical and electronic structure of FeN4 active sites and improve the utilization of active sites. Fig. 15(b) shows the size of tetraphenylporphyrin iron (Fe-TPP), ZIF with the sod topology (sod-ZIF) and ZIF with the rho topology (rho-ZIF) molecules. Taking advantage of the fact that the diameter of Fe-TPP molecules is smaller than that of rho-ZIF molecules, Cao’s group encapsulated Fe-TPP molecules in the rho-ZIF cage through the mechanization method, and prepared Fe-N-C catalyst with single iron atom loading up to 3.8 wt% after pyrolysis. The catalyst exhibited improved ORR activity and the E 1/2 reached 0.895 V in 0.1 M KOH. After 10,000 cycles of accelerated durability tests, it shows excellent stability [226]. Due to the limitation of host and guest, the agglomeration of single iron atoms is effectively avoided during the pyrolysis process. High iron loading and ultra-high specific surface area render the catalyst high ORR activity. Han et al. introduced the Fe-Phen complex (Fe2+ ions coordinated with 1,10-phenanthroline (Phen)) into the cavity in-situ during the formation process of ZIF-8, and prepared Fe-N X -C catalyst with highly dispersed atoms through pyrolysis (Fig. 15c) [227]. The E 1/2 of the prepared catalyst reached 0.91 V, and it has good stability and Zn-air battery performance (open circuit voltage E OCV = 1.51 V, power density W = 96.4 mW cm−2). Abundant nitrogen-containing species enable improving ORR activity: pyridine-N provides coordination sites for the formation of FeN X species, and graphitic-N improves the conductivity and limiting the current density of the catalyst. In conclusion, the cavity confinement strategy utilizes the cavity structure of MOFs to encapsulate the metal precursors. This spatial confinement effect enables avoiding the agglomeration of metal precursors in pyrolysis, thereby facilitating the formation of SACs. But there are also some drawbacks: 1) The size of metal precursors is limited. Since the cavity size of MOFs is fixed, the size of the packaged precursors must be smaller than the cavity size, which greatly limits the type of metal precursors; 2) Lack of general synthesis strategy. Due to the different sizes of the same type of metal precursors, it is difficult to have a general synthesis strategy similar to that of acetylacetone precursors; 3) Cavity structure is easy to collapse during the pyrolysis process. MOFs will collapse in pyrolysis, which leads to the overflow of metal precursors. Agglomeration will occur, which is not conducive to the formation of SACs. 4.3 Outer protection strategy The metal ions on the surface of unpyrolyzed MOFs present a highly dispersed single-atom state. But after pyrolysis, particularly owing to the high specific surface energy from the individual atoms, an agglomeration can occur, which greatly reduces the utilization efficiency of the metal catalytic active center. In addition, after high-temperature pyrolysis, the pore structure of MOFs collapses, not facilitating the catalyst mass transfer process and the exposure of more active sites [228–233]. Therefore, some measures should be taken to protect MOFs to promote the formation of high-density SACs and maintain the stability of the structure after pyrolysis. Commonly used protection strategies are mainly divided into the following two types: 1) Protection strategies for organic compounds, such as surfactants, enzymes, and polymers; 2) Host-guest strategies. 4.3.1 Organic compound protection strategy There are many types of organic compounds, and there are also differences in the outer protective mechanism. Surfactants have abundant hydrophilic groups and hydrophobic groups, which can be used as capping agents to adjust the crystallization process of MOFs. They are often divided into ionic surfactants (cationic and anionic surfactants), non-ionic surfactants, amphoteric surfactants, compound surfactants, and other surfactants [234–236]. Fig. 16 (a) illustrates the pyrolysis process of the Co-based SACs prepared by the surfactant-constrained pyrolysis strategy. Huang’s group used the surfactant's hydrophilic group to easily coordinate with zinc and cobalt ions to control the growth rate of cobalt-doped ZIFs, thereby controlling the size and morphology of the crystals [237]. During the pyrolysis process, the strong interaction between the surfactant and the ZIFs limits the single cobalt atom and avoids the agglomeration of single atoms. The restraining effect of the carbon shell formed after the surfactant carbonization also greatly reduces the collapse of the ZIFs internal microporous structure. The effects of different types of surfactants are also explored on crystal size. When the molecular weight of the surfactant increases, the crystal size decreases from 850 to 100 nm, which is caused by the different encapsulation capabilities of special surfactants. The size of the crystals also affects the catalytic activity. DFT calculation shows that CoN2+2 active site is more conducive to the occurrence of four-electron reaction pathway because CoN2+2 active site is more conducive to the breaking of O-O bond than CoN4 active site. In addition to surfactants, some other organic compounds can also be used as protective agents. Li and co-workers used the phenolic resin (RP)-assisted strategy to regulate the dynamic growth rate of the precursor by taking advantage of the fast nucleation rate of MOFs and slow polymerization rate of formaldehyde (AF) (Fig. 16b) [238]. The introduction of RP effectively restricted the cobalt sites on the ZIFs and avoided their agglomeration. It also forms a hierarchical porous structure. In addition, its introduction increased the total N content and the percentage of graphite-N and pyridine-N. This structure makes the catalyst have improved ORR activity and stability. Hu’s group took advantage of the characteristics of self-polymerization of dopamine (DPA) into polydopamine (PDA) under alkaline conditions to uniformly cover the protective layer of PDA on CoNi-MOFs to form the CoNi-MOFs@PDA core–shell structure (Fig. 16c) [239]. Nitrogen-doped hollow carbon catalysts supported on Co and Ni atoms were prepared by pyrolysis and acid washing. DFT calculations show that the dual-atom active center is beneficial to both the adsorption and dissociation of ORR intermediate species, and reduces the total potential barrier of the reaction. This strategy provides further understanding for the construction of multi-site electrocatalysts and the relationship between structure and performance in catalysis. Solvent-assisted ligand exchange and metal iron exchange strategies have been widely used in post-synthesis modification of MOFs [241–243]. Controllable ligand exchange can prevent large-volume ligands from entering the interior of MOFs, and can also realize the functionalization of metal cations to the surface of the MOFs. Ammonium ferric citrate (AFC) was used to functionalize the ZIF-8 surface. Fig. 16(d) illustrates the process of preparing C-AFC©ZIF-8 catalyst by ligand exchange strategy. A carbon-based catalyst was obtained, abundant with highly dispersed Fe atoms after pyrolysis [219]. Theoretical calculations show that the ion exchange is reluctant to take place between AFC and ZIF-8. This is owing to strong coordination between Fe and citrate ions. But as the strong coordination between Zn and citrate ions, the exchange can occur between citrate ions and dimethylimidazole ligands. After the ligand exchange, iron ions are uniformly doped into the ZIF-8 structure, and AFC plays a protective role in the carbonization process, facilitating the formation of single-atom active sites. Heteroatom doping in the carbon-based catalyst enables effectively tuning the electronic and spatial structures, and optimizes the charge and spin distribution of the material to effect the activity [202,244–247]. The common doping elements mainly include S, P and B. The differences of atomic radius and electronegativity between doped elements and nitrogen and carbon are used to tune the electronic structure of the MN X active center, leading to the optimal adsorption strength between the active site and the oxygen reduction intermediate, thus obtaining high catalytic activity [240,248–253]. Li and co-workers introduced the poly(cyclotriphospazene-co-4,4′-sulfonyldiphenol) (PZS) monomers and ferric salt into the synthesis process of ZIF-8 to afford the material with PZS@ZIF-8 core–shell structure (Fig. 16e) [240]. The polymer-based coating can adjust the electronic structure of the active metal centers through the Kirkendall effect and the long-range S-P interaction, which is helpful for the architecture of the hollow structure. The carbon-based catalysts doped with nitrogen, phosphorus and sulfur were prepared by pyrolysis of PZS@ZIF-8. DFT calculations showed that the introduction of S and P atoms can provide some electrons to the Fe atom center. At this time, the less positive charge of the Fe atom center is conducive to weakening the binding ability with OH* species.
