The introduction of heteroatoms can adjust and regulate the electronic structure of the iron active center to exhibit excellent ORR activity for both acidic and alkaline conditions. 4.3.2 Subject-object strategy The core–shell structure has promising prospects in catalysis due to its unique structural advantages. The Liquid-phase epitaxy growth method is popular to synthesize MOFs with core–shell structure. However, due to the anisotropic growth properties of MOFs, only a limited number of MOFs can be directly epitaxial grown on specific lattice-matched supports. The formed core–shell structure has good catalytic potential. The outer shell has high permeability and protection, and the internal cavity provides an additional three-phase interface and hierarchical porous structure, facilitating the mass transfer of reactants [1,10]. The researchers found that the NC hollow skeleton after carbonization of ZIF-8 is beneficial to the study of diffusion kinetics, and the highly graphitized Co-NGC shell formed after carbonization of ZIF-67 has high catalytic activity [254–256]. How to achieve high-density single-atom sites on carbon support with high conductivity and high porosity has become increasingly important. Lu and co-workers took zinc and cobalt-doped ZIFs as seeds and used the strategy of liquid-phase epitaxial growth to grow a layer of ZIF-67 structure on the surface to form the CoZn-ZIFs@ZIF-67 core–shell structure (Fig. 17 a) [257]. The core–shell Co-N3C1@GC catalyst was formed by pyrolysis and acid washing. The outer mesoporous graphitized carbon shell facilitating catalyzing mass transfer and electron transfer, and the inner carbon shell is loaded with an abundance of single-atom active sites. The electronic structures of active sites with different coordination were analyzed by DFT calculation. The optimized near-Fermi electronic state of CoN3C1 is conducive to the adsorption of oxygen molecules, and the adsorbed O2* is protonated to form OOH*. The E 1/2 reaches 0.846 V, and the large diffusion current-limited density is 5.16 mA/cm2. This method not only realizes the highly dispersed large-density single atoms in the carbon support with high conductivity and high porosity, but also optimizes the geometric structure and conductivity of the catalyst. Fig. 17(b) illustrates the formation process of the Fe-mIm NC@ZIF-8 composite structure. Chen and co-workers doped divalent iron ions in-situ into the ZIF structure and then were wrapped by ZIF-8 to form a core–shell Fe-mImNC@ZIF-8 [218]. After pyrolysis and acid washing, an electrocatalyst with highly dispersed single iron atoms was formed. The restriction effect of the ZIF-8 framework in the pyrolysis process facilitates the formation of single FeN X active sites. The coordination state of the FeN X site was adjusted by changing the ratio of a host to guest. The obtained catalyst has abundant FeN X active sites with five-coordination, and its current density is 5.12 mA/cm2 (at 0.4 V), which is higher than that of 5.81 mA/cm2 of 30% Pt/C. The E 1/2 was 0.735 V, only lower than 30% Pt/C (0.774 V). Combining experimental investigation and theoretical calculations, the five-coordinate structure FeN X active site was found to hold a lower reaction barrier, which reduces the adsorption of intermediate products and facilitates the improvement of ORR activity. The construction of order, customizable, porous structures, particularly hierarchical structures, plays a critical role in facilitating the mass transfer, particle dispersion, and facilitates the exposure of active sites. These structural properties are beneficial to the improvement of catalytic activity [229,259,260]. The formation process of Fe-doped ZIF-8 precursor with satellite structure prepared by self-assembly strategy is shown in Fig. 17(c). Wu’s group assembled Fe-doped ZIF-8 crystals with diverse particle sizes into satellite structures, in which the small particles of 30 nm were loaded onto the large particles of 100 nm. The FeN4 active sites were evenly distributed on porous carbon supports after pyrolysis [258]. This unique satellite structure avoids the aggregation and spatial overlap of small particles during the synthesis process, maximizing the exposure of catalytic active sites. Such a unique hierarchical structure facilitates catalytic mass transfer. Such a self-assembly strategy provides a new route for the structural design of novel catalysts. The outer protection strategy can effectively achieve morphological modulation and control particle size of MOFs, and plays an outer protection role in the pyrolysis process. This restriction can prevent structural collapse and aggregation of metal atoms, and maximize the utilization efficiency of metal atoms. But there are also some disadvantages: 1) It is challenging to accurately control crystal size with the outer protective agent. The same goes to control the selection and dosage of a protectant as a variety of coordination environments of metal ions exist; 2) The preparation method is complicated. It is often necessary to coat repeatedly on the basis of precursor synthesis, and other steps such as pyrolysis and pickling may be also required; 3) Protective agents are often organic compounds with some toxicity. 4.4 Phase diffusion strategy Wet chemical synthesis is often used to prepare SACs with MOFs as the precursor, that is, all the synthesized metal precursors are completed in a solvent. The metal ions are then reduced by carbon into single atoms in the precursor by pyrolysis and loaded into a NC skeleton. This traditional method suffers from complicated and cumbersome preparation [3,14,184,210,261]. In addition, due to the weak interaction between the single atoms and their support, it is inevitable that single atoms will agglomerate during the subsequent preparation and the catalytic reaction processes. If MOFs are used as the precursors, the diffusion characteristics of metal atoms at high temperatures are captured and reduced on the carbon support. This strong interaction can improve the high-temperature stability of the catalyst, and also provide a novel route to prepare SACs. The phase diffusion strategy is mainly divided into the following two methods: 1) Ball milling method (solid phase diffusion method); 2) Gas-phase diffusion method. 4.4.1 Ball milling strategy High-energy ball milling utilizes the rotation or vibration of ball mill to make the hard balls strongly impact, grind and stir the raw material powder, to realize the powder nano-crystallization [262–264]. This strategy can reduce the activation energy in the reaction, increase the reactant’s activity, and reduce the crystal to the nanoscale. In this process, the raw material has undergone the breaking and recombination of chemical bonds, which can achieve a solvent-free chemical reaction. This method can avoid the use of amounts of solvents (methanol, DMF) and auxiliary reagents (surfactants), reducing the pressure in the environment and the preparation cost [244]. It is also easy to realize large-scale preparation and has a wide range of application prospects. Liu et al. utilized the ball milling method to mechanically mix ferrous oxalate, dimethylimidazole and zinc oxide under the protection of nitrogen atmosphere to obtain Fe-doped ZIF-8 crystals (Fig. 18 a) [244]. The chemical bond between dimethylimidazole and zinc oxide was broken by ball milling, and the crystal structure of ZIF was formed by chemical bond recombination at high temperatures. After ball milling, ferrous oxalate is transformed into FeO X , which releases divalent iron ions in a similar coordination environment with zinc ions at high temperatures, and partially replaces zinc ions to form Fe-doped ZIF structure. After PVP coating and high-temperature pyrolysis, Fe-N-C catalyst with high-density single-atom dispersion was formed. The PVP coating effectively avoids the fusion between crystals and prevents the formation of larger particles, thereby ensuring a large specific surface area. The high-density single-atom sites and uniform crystal size make the catalyst exhibit excellent ORR activity and the improved performance of a PEMFC battery. Sun and co-workers successfully synthesized Fe-doped ZIF-8 using the ball milling assisted with the microwave-assisted method (Fig. 18b) [265]. They mechanically ball-milled iron acetate, dimethylimidazole and zinc oxide for 1 h under the protection of nitrogen atmosphere, and then used microwave radiation to form the ZnO@FeZn-ZIF structure. Fe-N-C SACs with mesoporous/microporous structures were prepared by pyrolysis in an ammonia atmosphere. The sacrificial ZnO template and the pyrolysis in NH3 atmosphere facilitates the formation of high-density single-atom active sites and hierarchical porous structure. These structures are conducive to the improvement of catalytic activity and mass transfer capacity, and E 1/2 reaches 0.782 V. Cao’s group mixed ZnO, Fe-TPP and diethylimidazole with the ball-milling method to realize the in-situ encapsulation of Fe-TPP in the cavity of the rho-ZIF structure, and obtained the composite structure Fe-TPP@rho-ZIFs (Fig. 18c) [226]. After pyrolysis, the iron atoms are highly dispersed in the N-doped carbon skeleton. This method can achieve high-density single atoms without solvent and acid treatment, proving the feasibility of the ball milling method to prepare SACs. At the molecular level, due to the restriction of host and guest actions, iron atoms are confined in the cavity, thereby obtaining a catalyst with amounts of FeN4 active sites. The high-density FeN4 active site and the unique structural advantage made the catalyst have superior ORR activity, and the E 1/2 reached 0.895 V (in 0.1 M KOH). The ball milling method uses the diffusion reaction of the solid phases at high temperatures to realize the chemical reaction without solvent participation. This preparation method avoids the waste of solvents and raw materials in the synthesis process of MOFs. As it is simple to operate, large-scale preparation can be realized. In summary, ball milling is an environmentally friendly, low-cost, operable and scalable method for preparing carbon-based catalysts. However, it also faces some disadvantages: 1) Low working efficiency and large energy consumption; 2) The agate ball has great friction with the outer wall, and the falling material will cause some pollution to the sample; 3) The application of the ball milling method to prepare SACs lacks a more practical and theoretical basis. 4.4.2 The gas-phase diffusion strategy The gas-phase diffusion transports the reacted metal species to the support in the form of the gas phases, where they are captured and reduced. Studies have shown that melamine or dicyandiamide will decompose into highly active nitrogen-containing gases at high temperatures. This gas can react with metals in-situ to generate metal-containing gas precursors, which are then captured by supports and reduced [267–269]. This preparation method avoids a large agglomeration of metal atoms on the support in the traditional pyrolysis method and is expected to realize SACs with high loading. Li and co-workers used the strong Lewis acid complexation between the corrosive gas NH3 and the atoms on the Cu foil surface towards volatile Cu(NH3) X species. At high temperatures, these volatile metal species will be captured by the nitrogen-doped carbon support obtained after carbonization by ZIF-8, resulting in excellent ORR performance and stability of Cu-SAs/N-C (Fig. 18d) [229]. The strategy can also be applied to other transition metals (e.g., Co and Ni). Metals exist mostly in the form of oxides under natural conditions. The use of corrosive gases also increases the cost and risk of experiments. As a consequence, it is particularly raring to develop a low-cost strategy for converting oxides directly into single-atom forms without the need for corrosive gases. Wu’s group used the general gas transport strategy to pyrolyze Cu2O and ZIF-8-derived NC in a nitrogen atmosphere to obtain Cu-ISAS/NC catalyst (Fig. 18e) [266]. Volatile metal oxides evaporate at high temperatures and are captured by nitrogen-rich carbon supports, resulting in M-ISAS/NC catalysts with highly dispersed metal atoms. The support with a high specific surface area provides plentiful space for loading single-atom active sites. The introduction of defects breaks the symmetric charge distribution at the single-atom Cu sites. The asymmetry of charge density distribution is mainly due to the synergistic effect of the introduction of defects and N coordination, which is conducive to the improvement of catalytic activity. The strategy avoids the use of corrosive gases, which is conducive to large-scale production and practical application and provides a valid route for the conversion of bulk oxides to single atoms. The aggregation of SACs at high temperatures has been a difficult problem. Li’s group reported an unexpected phenomenon in which noble-metal NPs were transformed into single atoms at high temperatures, confirming the successful reversal of the sintering phenomenon. Using ZIF-8-derived NC as a support, they confirmed the atomization process of Pb-NPs at high temperatures using in-situ environmental transmission electron microscopy (ETEM) and synchrotron radiation [28]. In addition to noble-metal NPs, Wu and co-workers also described the gradual conversion of Ni-NPs into single atoms at high temperatures [108]. He demonstrated that carbon supports with nitrogen defects can realize the transformation process from M−NPs to single atoms. This discovery breaks the traditional understanding of the formation process of SACs, can realize the revival of nano-catalysts and improve the industrial utilization efficiency of catalysts. In short, the gas-phase diffusion strategy provides a new way for the synthesis of SACs. It avoids the serious agglomeration process of metal precursors during pyrolysis. At high temperatures, the metal species are captured and reduced by the support in the form of the gas phases, so that the individual atom active sites are evenly distributed in the support. Although it is beneficial to the preparation of SACs, there remain some problems: 1) The conversion of pure metals to single atoms often requires the participation of corrosive gases, which increases the cost and risk of experiments; 2) Oxides often need to have volatility to meet the requirements of the gas-phase diffusion strategy, and not all oxides are volatile; 3) The strategy is not very universal; 4) The volatile species produced in the experimental process will cause some pollution to the heating equipment such as tube furnaces, resulting in some deviations in the experimental results. 4.5 Dual-template strategy The template strategy can control the morphology, structure and geometrical size of synthetic materials via the spatial confinement effect of the template itself. As an important mean for the synthesis of M−N−C catalyst, the template method lays the foundation [133,270–272]. MOFs are optimal precursors or templates for the synthesis of SACs. The introduction of an external template restricts the morphology and size of the MOFs. The metal atoms on the 3D framework can be well protected, effectively avoiding the agglomeration of single atoms during the pyrolysis process. According to whether extra cumbersome steps are needed to remove foreign templates after pyrolysis, this dual-template strategy is mainly divided into the following two categories: 1) One-step template method: PS and salt templates; 2) Multi-step template method: mesoporous SiO2, SiOX, and ordered mesoporous silicon. 4.5.1 One-step template method The one-step template method means that the foreign template can be removed without additional complex treatment during the synthesis process. The template is removed by pyrolysis and washing. This method requires the selection of templates. For example, it is easy to decompose at high temperatures to remove the template. The common templates are mainly some organic templates and salt templates. Huang’s group used the salt template method to introduce the KCl template into the synthesis process of the ZIF-67 to form the ZIF-67@KCl structure (Fig. 19 a) [237]. By using the spatial support function of KCl, the shrinkage and collapse of the ZIFs structure and the aggregation of cobalt atoms are effectively avoided. The Co-NPs were removed by hydrochloric acid pickling, and the KCl template was taken away with water, so that the high-density single cobalt atoms are highly dispersed in the nitrogen-containing 2D nanosheets. The high activity roots in the high-density CoN4 active sites in the carbon support and high specific surface area. The salt template method can be removed with water, and realizes the simple and efficient preparation of high-density SACs. Besides the salt template method, the organic template method is also widely utilized for the synthesis of carbon-based catalysts [272,275]. The polystyrene spheres (PS) template is a commonly used organic template, which is a good precursor for constructing an ordered mesoporous structure. Studies have shown that electrocatalytic activity mainly depends on the intrinsic activity and amounts of catalytic sites. The construction of the orderly hierarchical porous structure is crucial in increasing the number of catalytic sites [246,276–280]: 1) The macropores (>50 nm) and mesopores (2–50 nm) are beneficial to the catalytic mass transfer. The reactants enable fully reaching the active center of the catalyst, and improving the catalytic efficiency; 2) The micropores (<2 nm) can contain more active sites and achieve the high catalytic activity. Wang and co-workers synthesized the Fe-ZIF-8@PS composite structure by using the method of two-solvent-induced heterogeneous nucleation and forced molding of the PS template (Fig. 19b) [273]. The FeN4-HOPC catalysts with the hierarchical porous structure were obtained by pyrolysis. The introduction of the PS template can effectively protect the Fe-doped ZIF-8 crystal, avoiding the collapse and the aggregation of single atoms during pyrolysis. In addition, a hierarchical porous structure is formed, which promotes the catalytic mass transfer process and accommodates a large number of active sites. Zhao’s group combined the PS template forming with the chemical impregnation method to synthesize Fe, Ni-ZIF-8@PS structure (Fig. 19c) [274]. During the pyrolysis process, the PS template and ZIF-8 structure were carbonized, and the Fe/Ni-N X /OC catalyst with highly dispersed Fe and Ni atoms, octahedral shape and hierarchical porous structure was realized. The E 1/2 was 0.938 V in 0.1 M KOH and 0.84 V in 0.1 M KClO4 respectively. The excellent ORR activity is rooted in the synergistic effect between the dual metal atoms and the superiorities of the hierarchical porous structure. This method can realize the rapid removal of foreign templates without any complicated and cumbersome processing. It is simpler and more efficient than the pickling method to remove the template. In addition to the limited protection of MOFs, it can also regulate the hierarchical porous structure of the catalyst. But this method also has certain drawbacks: 1) The synthesis of organic templates often requires organic solvents, which is not friendly to the environment; 2) The products of organic templates pollute the catalyst during the pyrolysis process; 3) Acid leaching is also needed to treat M−NPs after pyrolysis in the salt template method. 4.5.2 Multi-step template method For the multi-step template method, the foreign template can be removed by further complicated processing during the catalyst preparation process. Common templates mainly include mesoporous SiO2, silicon oxide, ordered mesoporous silicon and etc. This template has high stability and can be removed by HF and strong alkali solutions after pyrolysis. The silicon oxide template has a strong limiting effect on the morphology and structure of the crystal. It can effectively avoid the aggregation of individual atoms in the pyrolysis process, and has an extensive application prospect in the synthesis of SACs [133,281–283]. The MOFs will shrink and collapse during the pyrolysis process, giving rise to the destruction of the internal microporous structure. The catalyst activity depends largely on the utilization efficiency of the active sites. SACs have high atomic utilization efficiency, which cannot reach 100% atomic utilization efficiency due to the existence of unexposed active sites [97,287]. How to maximize the use of these metal sites while achieving high-density single metal atom sites? Most ORR processes occur at the three-phase interface (catalyst-electrolyte-oxygen), so the structure of catalyst is particularly important for the improvement of catalytic activity [288–290]. Shui’s group formed a SiO2 coating on the ZIF-8 structure to maintain the edge frame of the rhomboid dodecahedron (Fig. 20 a) [284]. The template was removed by acid etching, and the main structure with a certain negative potential and concave morphology was obtained. Subsequently, the positively charged TPI ([Fe(Phen)3]2+, a Fe(II)-Phenanthroline) complex was adsorbed to the main body, and the TPI@Z8(SiO2)-650-C with high-density single atoms was generated after pyrolysis. The thickness of the SiO2 shell layer will have effects on the morphology. Only when the thickness is appropriate, the edge of the frame can be maintained to form a sharp-edged concave structure. This structure can maximize the utilization efficiency of active sites and enhance the catalytic mass transfer process, improve the utilization efficiency of active sites, and lead to Fe-N-C SACs with high ORR activity. Xu and co-workers also used the silica template method to prepare Fe-OES catalyst with a suspended eave structure and modified by single iron atom active sites (Fig. 20b) [285]. They first used ZIF-8 as the main body to encapsulate the iron acetylacetone precursor, and then covered the surface with silicon oxide as the armor to form the Fe/ZIF-8@SiOX structure. The SiOX coating plays a key part in the morphology control of the catalyst. It can avoid the collapse in the pyrolysis process to the maximum extent, and is also conducive to the formation of edge structure, so as to expose more three-phase interfaces. This unique structure is conducive to the improvement of the utilization efficiency of the catalytic active center. The catalyst exhibits excellent ORR activity (E 1/2 = 0.85 V in 0.1 M KOH, E 1/2 is only lower than commercial Pt/C 15 mV in acidic system) in both alkaline and acidic media, which is superior to most reported precious metal catalysts. The ordered mesoporous structure can unlock the steric hindrance and mass transfer resistance, and improve the contact between active sites and reactants and utilization efficiency of metal active centers. Sun’s group took ordered mesoporous silicon (KIT-16) as a hard template and filled the Fe(II)-Phen complex and dimethylimidazole in the pore channels. After high-temperature pyrolysis and HF etching, Fe-based SACs supported on 3D ordered mesoporous carbon were formed (Fig. 20c) [286]. DFT showed that the FeN4 active sites doped on the graphene skeleton had moderate adsorption energy with oxygen-containing intermediates, which improved the intrinsic activity of the active sites. Fe-N-C/N-OMC showed higher half-wave potential, kinetic current density, TOF and mass activity in alkaline electrolytes. Jiang et al. introduced SiO2 into the mesoporous of porphyrin MOFs (PCN-222 (Fe)). After removing the template by high-temperature pyrolysis and pickling, Fe-based SACs with Fe loading up to 3.46 wt% were obtained [291]. The spatial barrier formed by the periodic arrangement of the linker and the interaction between SiO2 and iron atoms avoids the aggregation of iron atoms to a large extent. Well, this method lays the foundation for the synthesis of high-loading SACs. Some hard templates have sufficient stability at high temperatures, which can well prevent the structure destruction of MOFs in the pyrolysis process and can also realize the control of the catalyst morphology. Meanwhile, hard templates have rich sources, low cost, and higher stability compared with organic templates. But there are some disadvantages: 1) The removal of the template often requires strong acid or alkali media, and the experimental conditions are harsh. Meanwhile, this process will also cause some damage to the original structure of the catalyst, and secondary pyrolysis is often needed to repair the damaged carbon structure; 2) The template often contains impurities in the catalyst due to an incomplete removal. 5 Summary and perspective Through using modified or processed MOFs as the main precursors, this review proposes several strategies to achieve the effective preparation of TM-SACs and summarizes the important progress in the characterization techniques of TM-SACs. Although MOFs have afforded some breakthroughs in the field of preparing TM-SACs, there remain some issues to address [156,157]: 1) The structural instability. The instability of MOFs leads to structural collapse in the pyrolysis process. Meanwhile, in the process of catalytic reaction, similar to other support supported SACs, the agglomeration of individual atoms may occur; 2) The synthesis method is complicated and unfriendly to the environment. The preparation of precursors is usually carried out in organic solvents. As the cost is relatively high, it is not easy to achieve large-scale preparation. Subsequently, it often requires one or more pyrolysis to be converted into the TM-SACs; 3) It is difficult to realize high-loading SACs. Theoretically, SACs have high atom utilization efficiency. But due to the limitation of the synthesis methods themselves, the metallic components are considerably wasted; 4) It is challenging to afford the controllable formation of SACs. The coordination structure of single metal atom centers needs to be delicately controlled. Such complex is correlated to the pyrolysis and synthesis conditions; 5) There is a long way to realize industrialization at present. The cost of the preparation method is relatively high, and SACs still lack sufficient stability for practical application; 6) Dual/multi-metal catalysts based on MOFs remain in their infancy, and more mechanistic exploration is needed to conduct via the clarification of the structure and properties of the catalysts. Although there is still a challenging task to tackle, the way of preparing TM-SACs based on MOFs is still ongoing. Continued efforts are being made to search for new strategies and to practically explore the relationship between catalyst performance and structural features. By taking advantage of the excellent characteristics of MOFs, we strive to realize TM-SACs with high loading capacity, high stability and high catalytic activity [155]. At present, the main issues include the following aspects: 1) Making full use of the structural diversity of MOFs and propose some new strategies to prepare TM-SACs. TM-SACs are mainly prepared with ZIFs, and other MOFs with other structures can be fully excavated for the preparation. According to the different physical/chemical and structural properties of different kinds of MOFs, the existing modification strategies can be treated to realize the preparation of TM-SACs; 2) The active center of TM-SACs is usually TM-N4. This coordination structure is considered to have high ORR activity. By regulating the coordination structure of the active centers, their activity can be further improved. Wang et al. found that the synergistic effect of Co-NPs and Co-N4 active sites effectively regulates the valence state of a single cobalt atom, which is conducive to the adsorption of oxygen reduction intermediates and promotes the reaction process in the alkaline environment [292]. Sun and co-workers also revealed for the first time that the synergistic catalysis of M−NPs and single-atom FeN4 active site was conducive to the oxygen reduction reaction under acidic conditions [200]. Wu’s group loaded the single cobalt site on the carbon-doped boron nitride (BCN) support, and the introduction of B provided an additional electric field effect for the support, which was conducive to the adsorption of the reactants [293]. Currently, the existing adjustment methods mainly include the construction of dual-atom active centers, the introduction of non-metals (S, P, B), the synergistic catalysis of M−NPs and single atoms, and the construction of guest groups. These strategies are still in the initial stage of exploration, and further development is expected to perfect the active sites of catalysts; 3) To increase the loading capacity of individual transition-metallic atoms. The activity of the catalyst is closely correlated to the amounts of catalytic sites and intrinsic activity. For TM-SACs, the aggregation of single atoms is avoided to the maximum extent during the synthesis process. The utilization efficiency of transition metals is improved, and the metal sites in the MOFs are converted to the TM-N X structure as possible as it can; 4) To realize the large-scale preparation and general strategy of TM-SACs. Excessive metal concentration gives rise to the agglomeration of single atoms in the preparation process. Therefore, due to the harsh preparation conditions of SACs, the loading from each synthesis is very low. Few kinds of literature report the large-scale preparation of SACs. It is difficult to realize the generalization of preparation strategies because of the different coordination environments, as well as the physical and chemical properties of different metals. Therefore, it is very important to develop a new strategy to realize the large-scale and general preparation of TM-SACs; 5) Using the advanced characterization methods and in-situ technologies, the structure of the catalyst is analyzed at an atomic level to explore the relationship between structure and performance. These techniques provide guidance for the design of TM-SACs prepared from MOFs; 6) To explore the ORR kinetics and optimal reaction path of TM-SACs in combination with theoretical calculations. Thus, it enables determining the true active sites of the electrocatalyst and the decisive step of the reaction process. This provides theoretical support for the structural design of the catalyst, so as to improve the performance of TM-SACs. Electrocatalytic activity is closely related to the fine structure of the active site. The electronic structure of metal sites (d-band positions, Fermi levels, work functions) largely determines the intrinsic activity of catalytic sites. Many factors such as adsorption of active sites and reactive species, reaction path and surface charge distribution, are closely related to the catalytic reaction mechanism. Using the advanced in-situ techniques to detect the dynamic changes of active sites during the reaction process can effectively realize the in-depth discussion of the dynamic reaction mechanism of ORR. The preparation strategy of TM-SACs based on MOFs has a wide range of application prospects. Their catalytic activity and stability are comparable to some noble metals, which provides the possibility for practical applications. By optimizing and improving the strategy of preparing TM-SACs based on MOFs, it is crucial to the development of TM-SACs in the future. Kexin Song obtained his bachelor’s degree at Changchun University of Science and Technology in 2017. He is currently a Master candidate under the supervision of Professor Wei Zhang at Jilin University. His current research focuses on the design, synthesis and application of carbon-based electrocatalytic materials. Yu Feng obtained her bachelor’s degree at University of Jinan in 2017. She is currently a Master candidate under the supervision of Professor Wei Zhang at Jilin University. Her current research focuses on the design, synthesis and application of electrocatalytic materials via biomass route. Wei Zhang obtained his Ph.D degree at the Institute of Metal Research (IMR) Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2004. He was awarded Ikerbasque Research Professor in 2016. In 2014, he became a full professor at Jilin University (Later as Tang-Auchin Scholar-Leading Professor); since 2017, he has served as the Director of the Electron Microscopy Center of Jilin University. His current research focuses on surface and interface of advanced energy materials and catalysts. Weitao Zheng is Cheung Kong Distinguished Professor and Vice President of Jilin University. He obtained his Ph.D. degree at Jilin University in 1990. After that he held positions in Royal Institute of Sweden, Linköping University, Chiba Institute of Technology and Nanyang University of Technology. His current research focuses on energy materials, functional thin films and catalysts.

coredata.dc:description: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been widely used in oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) of fuel cells and metal-air batteries, attributed to their unique structures and compositions. Recently, the preparation of transition-metallic single-atom electrocatalysts (TM-SACs) using MOFs as precursors or templates has made great progress. Herein, the development history of SACs prepared based on MOFs and their characterization are overviewed firstly, and then several strategies are summarized for preparing TM-SACs using MOFs and further modification. Finally, the challenges and opportunities confronted by TM-SACs are fully discussed. Consequently, our work can guide the realization of TM-SACs abundant with high activity, high loading and high stability.

coredata.dc:title: MOFs fertilized transition-metallic single-atom electrocatalysts for highly-efficient oxygen reduction: Spreading the synthesis strategies and advanced identification
